awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking sea ice and snow cover changes to Greenland mass balance through stratospheric and tropospheric pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Melting of the Greenland ice sheet is already the largest single contributor to sea level rise, and the rate of melt is accelerating.  At the same time, the Arctic as a whole is experiencing unprecedented changes and setting new records, including the decline of Arctic sea ice cover, the decline and early snowmelt onset of Northern Hemisphere snow cover, and an overall warming at a rate more than double anywhere else on the planet.  Studying and understanding the mechanisms linking the different Arctic components (Greenland, snow cover, and sea ice in the case of this research) and how, in turn, their changes are related to and driven by the atmosphere is fundamental to capture the physical processes driving the changes. This is, indeed, one of the key aspects to considerably improve our skills in estimating the future evolution of the Arctic under different warming scenarios and in projecting future sea level rise.

This research is quantifying the relationships between sea ice, snow cover, atmospheric circulation changes and mass changes over the Greenland ice sheet through a combination of observational and modeling tools. These include in situ observations of sea ice cover and snow extent as well as remote sensing products and estimates of atmospheric circulation changes and outputs from climate models. We also use artificial intelligence (e.g., neural networks) to examine relationships between climate, atmospheric patterns and Greenland changes. Ultimately, this research is testing the hypothesis that atmospheric circulation changes associated with sea ice and snow cover extent variability control the mass balance of the Greenland ice sheet by modulating snowfall and surface melting. This research is also providing new insights on the linkages between the Arctic and mid-latitudes and how sea ice and snow cover changes might affect weather patterns outside the Arctic, including the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
PI Cohen

I contributed to the manuscript currently in review that argues accelerated melting of spring snow cover across North America is contributing to increased Greenland ice melt in the summer.

I am also analyzing the winter of 2013/14. This recent winter is when the term ?polar vortex? became popular in the media, this despite that based on current understanding the ?polar vortex? did not influence the weather that winter (associated with a complete breakdown of the polar vortex).  We found that that winter did have the most frequent occurrences where the polar vortex stretches rather than becomes highly distorted or breaks down. Little is known about these events, yet they can have a large impact on the weather including Greenland.  Besides the winter of 2013/14 we are looking more generally at these events for a more complete understanding.  One manuscript is in press at JGR-Atmospheres.

In a review article, we argue why consensus on the topic of Arctic mid-latitude linkages remains challenging.  The article summarizes the regional impacts of Arctic amplification or accelerated Arctic warming on Asia, Europe and North America.  The article also divides Arctic influence through tropospheric and stratospheric pathways.

We have also been exploring more in depth the relationship between polar vortex variability and the tropospheric circulation and weather.  We compared the tropospheric precursors and the influence on our weather due to large polar vortex disruptions in both observations and numerical models. 

I have also contributed to publications looking at how warming soils are contributing to accelerated spring snow melt and how changes in the atmospheric circulation in the North Atlantic sector is contributing to accelerated warming in the Barents-Kara Seas region.

 

PIs Tedesco and Mote

Spatial downscaling work: PI Tedesco is utilizing machine learning methods, in particular the method of Generalized Adversarial Networks (GANs) to produce hyper-resolution (10-100m) fields of surface mass balance quantities through the fusion of regional climate model data (e.g. MAR) and remote sensing observations.

Linking Greenland surface processes to atmospheric drivers: Machine learning can also be used to bridge the gap between multi-scale surface and atmospheric processes, providing insights into the role of different drivers that are ultimately controlling the evolution of surface melt and surface mass balance. Dr. Tedesco and team are utilizing Random Forest Modeling in conjunction with Shapley game theory analysis to identify the relative importance of different drivers in Greenland surface processes.

Improving understanding of drivers of local surface variability: Dr. Tedesco and team are also investigating the use of machine learning tools to reveal relationships between surface processes and atmospheric drivers that are currently poorly understood and under-represented in models. Specifically, we are using climate model simulations and remote sensing data to better understand relationships between atmospheric drivers and bare ice surface albedo in the Greenland ice sheet ablation zone.

Investigating the shift in summer circulation over Greenland in the context of Arctic amplification: We reveal a statistically significant (ɑ=0.05) positive trend in the waviness of summer atmospheric circulation over the North Atlantic and show that this increase in waviness is accompanied by collocated reductions in the magnitude of the meridional temperature gradient and the strength of upper-level zonal wind.

We also investigate the direct influence of retreating spring snow cover on circulation over Greenland and show a clear negative lagged correlation relating both atmospheric waviness over the North Atlantic and Greenland blocking during July to North American snow cover extent area during the preceding spring. We summarize our results of our investigation into the mechanisms behind this delayed atmospheric response in Fig. 1. Low spring snow cover leads to early depletion of soil moisture and dry surface conditions over North America that persist into July. The consequent anomalous heating of the lower atmosphere forces a wave that favors high pressure ridging over Greenland and widespread melt of the Greenland Ice Sheet. We have submitted a manuscript summarizing this work to be considered for publication in Nature Communications.

Quantifying the contribution of background thermodynamic change to Greenland Ice Sheet surface mass loss using the pseudo-global warming method: Working in close collaboration with PI Tedesco and collaborators Patrick Alexander and Xavier Fettwies, we have begun conducting a pseudo-global warming (PGW) experiment aimed at quantifying the relative roles of dynamic versus thermodynamic change to the recent acceleration of Greenland Ice Sheet surface runoff.

We present a model diagram of our experimental design in Fig. 2. Here we use the regional climate model MAR (Mod?le Atmosph?rique R?gionale) forced by ERA5 reanalysis data (Hersbach et al, 2020) from the period of 2000-2019 that has been adjusted to reflect the thermodynamic background state of 1880-1889. In doing so, we aim to quantify what the change in Greenland Ice Sheet surface mass balance would have been if the recent shift in summer atmospheric circulation had occurred under a preindustrial climate.
